topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Enabling LDAP

body.p: The HPE Helion OpenStack Identity service can use Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) to integrate your organization's existing directory service and user account management processes. LDAP integration can be performed during the HPE Helion OpenStack installation process.
body.section:
Enabling LDAP Before HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is Installed
If HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is not installed, use the following steps to enable LDAP.Configure LDAP Before installation
Set up the LDAP server, before installing HP Helion OpenStack Carrier GRade. The LDAP server needs to be running, and reachable by the nodes.
Create admin and service accounts. The service accounts need to have suitably named users and passwords created in the correct group on the LDAP server, with suitable permissions for the admin user.
Edit the definitions.json file several variables are needed under ansible-vars, to proceed with an LDAP enabled cloud."ldap_url": "10.1.64.20" (url of the LDAP server) "ldap_username": "admin" (username of the admin account) "ldap_password": "admin" (password of the admin account) "ldap_domain": "dc=cdl,dc=local" (domain of the LDAP server) "ldap_ou": "CG-Test-Users" (OU to be used for this cloud) "ldap_enabled": 1 (variable to determine if the LDAP enabling steps are done)
Install HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade Once the variables are set correctly, the cloud can be deployed as normal via hdeploy. This should cause the cloud to be deployed as normal, followed by the LDAP enabling roles that will follow.

Enabling LDAP After HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is Installed
If HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade is already installed, use the following steps to enable LDAP.Deploy LDAP support after cloud deployment

ol.li: Edit the /<Cloud Name>/clouds/<Cloud Name>/001/stage/ansible/top_level_playbooks/commit/ to comment-out roles.
Edt the: /<Cloud Name>/clouds/<Cloud Name>/001/stage/ansible/ to comment-out roles.
Edit the build-CCP-T<1-3>.yml to comment out all roles that except LDP-CCN.

Before you run, if this code has been run in the past and you are running it again due to a failure of some kind, you need to check the assignments database and delete any records that have an actor_id that is not a GUID.
For example:Actor_id = ‘admin’ Actor_id = ‘ceilometer’ Actor_id = ‘cinder’
The roles need to be removed. Leaving only the records with a 16 digit hex number for actor_id. The playbook will attempt to create these records and it will fail if they exist already.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.p: If you have any issues with the enablement, see the following troubleshooting tips.

ul.li: Verify users in LDAP server; sometimes users can be created without privileges, typos in username or passwords.

Check /etc/keystone/keystone.conf on controller nodes to make sure the playbook ran correctly and finished setting all LDAP settings with the variables set above.
If anything differs, or does not exist, the LDAP code was not run or the variables were not set correctly.
These values can be set manually if there was a typo, or the LDAP section of the ansible playbooks can be run by themselves.

Check /etc/glance/glance-cache.conf, glance-api.conf, and glance-registry.conf to make sure the admin_user, and admin_password match what is in the LDAP server.
If anything differs, or does not exist, the LDAP code was not run or the variables were not set correctly.
These values can be set manually if there was a typo, or the LDAP section of the ansible playbooks can be run by themselves.

Check /etc/cinder/cinder.conf to make sure the admin_user, and admin_password match what is in the LDAP server.
If anything differs, or does not exist, the LDAP code was not run or the variables were not set correctly.
These values can be set manually if there was a typo, or the LDAP section of the ansible playbooks can be run by themselves.

Check /etc/nova/nova.conf to make sure the neutron_admin_user, neutron_admin_password, admin_user, admin_password, match what is in the LDAP server.
If anything differs, or doesn’t exist the LDAP code either wasn’t run, or the variables weren’t set correctly.
These values can be set manually if there was a typo, or the LDAP section of the ansible playbooks can be run by themselves.

Log into MySQL and select the Keystone database. Execute the select * from assignments; query to confirm that there are entries for each user in the table. These users should have the LDAP username in the actor_id column, and there should be two for each user (with 6 for admin). If this is not the case, the MysSQL script did not run in the playbook and should be run again.
